title: Present Simple Tense
description: Learn the basics of present simple tense formation and usage

content.explanation: The present simple tense is used to describe habits, facts, and general truths.
examples: The sun rises in the east.
rules: Use base form of verb for I, you, we, they
Add -s or -es for he, she, it
Use do/does for questions and negatives

title: Articles: A, An, The
description: Master the correct usage of definite and indefinite articles

content.explanation: Articles are words that define a noun as specific or unspecific.

title: Past Simple vs Present Perfect
description: Understand when to use past simple versus present perfect tense

content.explanation: Past simple is for completed actions at specific times, present perfect connects past to present.
examples: I visited Paris last year. (past simple)
rules: Past simple: specific time in the past
Present perfect: experience or continuing relevance

title: Prepositions of Time
description: Learn when to use at, in, on for time expressions

content.explanation: Prepositions of time show when something happens.

title: Subject and Object Pronouns
description: Distinguish between subject pronouns (I, you, he) and object pronouns (me, you, him)

content.explanation: Subject pronouns perform the action, object pronouns receive the action.
examples: I see him. (I = subject, him = object)
She gave me a book. (she = subject, me = object)
rules: Subject pronouns: I, you, he, she, it, we, they
Object pronouns: me, you, him, her, it, us, them

title: First Conditional
description: Learn to express real possibilities with if-clauses

content.explanation: First conditional expresses real or likely future situations.
examples: If it rains, I will stay home.
If you study hard, you will pass the exam.
rules: If + present simple, will + base verb
Can use unless instead of if not

title: Comparative and Superlative Adjectives
description: Form and use comparative and superlative adjectives correctly

content.explanation: Comparative adjectives compare two things, superlatives compare three or more.

title: Present Continuous Tense
description: Express ongoing actions happening now

content.explanation: Present continuous describes actions happening right now or temporary situations.
examples: She is studying English this year.

title: Nouns: Types and Usage
description: Master different types of nouns and their grammatical functions

content.explanation: Nouns are words that name people, places, things, or ideas. They can be concrete or abstract.
rules: Common nouns are not capitalized unless at sentence start
Collective nouns can be singular or plural

title: Verbs: Action and Linking
description: Understand action verbs, linking verbs, and helping verbs

content.explanation: Verbs express actions, states of being, or help other verbs complete their meaning.
rules: Action verbs show what the subject does
Linking verbs connect subject to complement

title: Adverbs: Modifying and Describing
description: Learn how adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, and other adverbs

content.explanation: Adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs, often ending in -ly.

title: Interjections: Expressing Emotion
description: Use interjections to express strong feelings and emotions

content.explanation: Interjections are words or phrases that express strong emotion or sudden feeling.
rules: Can stand alone or within sentences

title: Conjunctions: Connecting Words
description: Master coordinating, subordinating, and correlative conjunctions

content.explanation: Conjunctions connect words, phrases, or clauses in sentences.
rules: FANBOYS: for, and, nor, but, or, yet, so

title: Metaphors: Implied Comparisons
description: Create powerful imagery using metaphors in writing and speech

content.explanation: Metaphors compare two unlike things without using 'like' or 'as', creating vivid imagery.
examples: Her voice is music to my ears
rules: Often used for emotional or descriptive effect

title: Similes: Direct Comparisons
description: Use similes to make clear comparisons using 'like' or 'as'

content.explanation: Similes compare two different things using 'like' or 'as' to create vivid descriptions.

title: Personification: Giving Life to Objects
description: Bring inanimate objects to life through personification

content.explanation: Personification gives human characteristics to non-human things.
examples: The wind whispered through the trees
The sun smiled down on us
rules: Gives human traits to non-human things
Often used in poetry and creative writing

title: Hyperbole: Deliberate Exaggeration
description: Use hyperbole for emphasis and dramatic effect

content.explanation: Hyperbole uses deliberate and obvious exaggeration for emphasis or effect.
examples: I've told you a million times
I'm so hungry I could eat a horse

title: Alliteration: Repetitive Sounds
description: Create rhythm and emphasis through alliteration

content.explanation: Alliteration repeats the same consonant sound at the beginning of nearby words.

title: Onomatopoeia: Sound Words
description: Use words that imitate the sounds they represent

content.explanation: Onomatopoeia uses words that phonetically imitate the sound they describe.
examples: The door slammed with a bang
rules: Words sound like what they describe
Common in comic books and children's literature

title: Irony: Contrast and Contradiction
description: Understand situational, verbal, and dramatic irony

content.explanation: Irony involves contrast between expectation and reality, or between literal and intended meaning.
examples: Verbal irony: 'Great weather!' during a storm
Situational irony: Fire station burns down
Dramatic irony: Reader knows what character doesn't
rules: Verbal irony says opposite of what's meant
Dramatic irony creates tension in stories

title: Oxymoron: Contradictory Terms
description: Use contradictory words together for effect

content.explanation: Oxymoron combines contradictory or opposing terms to create a paradoxical effect.
rules: Often used for humor or to highlight complexity
